musical_form.description: The Fuchsia Pregnancy is a form of music used to commemorate important events originating in The Tombs-Roads of Equivalence. The form guides musicians during improvised performances. A chanter recites nonsensical words and sounds while the music is played on a leshal and a zilir. The music is melody and rhythm without harmony. The melody has phrases of varied length throughout the form. Never more than an interval sounds at once. The music repeats for as long as necessary. It is performed using the izeg scale and in the libash rhythm. Throughout, when possible, performers are to locally improvise and modulate frequently. [B]The chanter always provides the rhythm and should be fiery. The voice uses its entire range. [B]The leshal always provides the rhythm and should be bright. [B]The zilir always does the main melody and should feel heroic. [B]The Fuchsia Pregnancy has a simple structure: three to four lengthy unrelated passages. [B]Each of the simple passages is moderately fast, and it is to be loud. Each passage should sometimes include a falling melody pattern with flattened third degree as well as mordents. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. [B]As always, the izeg pentatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named anam and ustos. [B]The anam trichord is the 1st, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The ustos trichord is the 1st, the 3rd and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The libash rhythm is a single line with four beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Satiny Blossom is a form of music used during marches and military engagements originating in The Tombs-Roads of Equivalence. The rules of the form are applied by composers to produce individual pieces of music which can be performed. A chanter recites nonsensical words and sounds. The entire performance is to be in whispered undertones. The melody has phrases of varied length throughout the form. Only one pitch is ever played at a time. It is performed using the gost scale and in the nel rhythm. Throughout, when possible, composers and performers are to use grace notes, alternate tension and repose and modulate frequently. [B]The chanter always does the main melody. [B]The Satiny Blossom has a well-defined multi-passage structure: a lengthy introduction, three to four unrelated passages, a lengthy bridge-passage and a finale. [B]The introduction should be made with feeling and is at a hurried pace. The chanter's voice covers its entire range. [B]Each of the simple passages should feel mournful and is slow. The chanter's voice stays in the high register. [B]The bridge-passage should be lively and is very fast. The chanter's voice ranges from the middle register to the high register. The passage should be composed and performed using legato. [B]The finale should be made sweetly and is consistently slowing. The chanter's voice stays in the middle register. [B]Scales are conceived of as two chords built using a division of the perfect fourth interval into eight notes. The tonic note is a fixed tone passed from teacher to student. [B]As always, the gost hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named anam and zustash. [B]The anam trichord is the 1st, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The zustash tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 6th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The nel rhythm is made from two patterns: the libash (considered the primary) and the feb. The patterns are to be played over the same period of time, concluding together regardless of beat number. [B]The libash rhythm is a single line with four beats. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - - x | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar. [B]The feb rhythm is a single line with twenty-nine beats divided into five bars in a 4-5-9-7-4 pattern. The beat is stressed as follows:[B]| - - x - | x - x x x | - - - - x - - - - | x x x x x x x | x x - - | [B]where x is a beat, - is silent and | indicates a bar.

The Pregnancy of Queens is a form of music used for entertainment originating in The Tombs-Roads of Equivalence. [B]In the introduction, the nubam ranges from the harsh high register to the strident top register. Chords are packed close together in dense clusters in this passage. The passage is performed using the kulet scale. [B]In each of the first simple passages, the nubam ranges from the buzzy low register to the strident middle register. Only one pitch is ever played at a time in this passage. Each passage is performed using the bem�ng scale. [B]In each of the second simple passages, the nubam covers its entire range from the buzzy low register to the strident top register. This passage is richly layered with full chords making use of the available range. Each passage is performed using the gost scale. [B]As always, the kulet heptatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named alak and sedil. [B]The alak tetrachord is the 1st, the 5th, the 6th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The sedil tetrachord is the 1st, the 2nd, the 6th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]As always, the bem�ng pentatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named bidok and gatal. [B]The bidok trichord is the 1st, the 7th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The gatal trichord is the 1st, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]As always, the gost hexatonic scale is thought of as two disjoint chords drawn from the fundamental division of the perfect fourth. These chords are named anam and zustash. [B]The anam trichord is the 1st, the 5th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division. [B]The zustash tetrachord is the 1st, the 3rd, the 6th and the 8th degrees of the fundamental perfect fourth division.
